case_name: Andheri Marol Kurla Bus Service and H. Khan v. State

facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 46 of 1957 in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 46 of 1957. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the February 4, 1955, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 1256 of 1954, arising out of the judgment and order dated June 19, 1954, of the Chief Presidency Magistrate, Bombay, in Case No. 176/S of 1953.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Bombay High Court judgment dated February 4, 1955 in Criminal Appeal No. 1256 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the February 4, 1955, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 1256 of 1954, arising out of the judgment and order dated June 19, 1954, of the Chief Presidency Magistrate, Bombay, in Case No. 176/S of 1953. Hardayal Hardy, for the appellants.

facts.text: Bombay High Court appeal arose from Chief Presidency Magistrate judgment dated June 19, 1954 in Case No. 176/S of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the February 4, 1955, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 1256 of 1954, arising out of the judgment and order dated June 19, 1954, of the Chief Presidency Magistrate, Bombay, in Case No. 176/S of 1953.

facts.text: Appellants are Andheri Marol Kurla Bus Service (accused No. 1, appellant No. 1) and its Manager H. Khan (accused No. 5, appellant No. 2).

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are the Andheri Marol Kurla Bus Service who was accused No. 1  number appellant No. 1  and its Manager H. Khan who was accused No. 5  number appellant No. 2 . Some disputes arose between the appellant No. 1 and its workmen.

facts.text: Disputes arose between appellant No. 1 and its workmen.

anchor.surface_text: Some disputes arose between the appellant No. 1 and its workmen. On December 13, 1951, the Conciliation Officer wrote to the appellant No. I and enclosed the demands of the Union which were dated August 9, 1951.

facts.text: Union demands dated August 9, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: On December 13, 1951, the Conciliation Officer wrote to the appellant No. I and enclosed the demands of the Union which were dated August 9, 1951. On December 31, 1951, the appellant No. I was asked to appear before the Conciliation Officer on January 9, 1952, and after getting one adjournment the appellant No. I appeared before the Conciliation Officer on January 17, 1952

facts.text: On December 13, 1951, Conciliation Officer wrote to appellant No. 1 enclosing Union demands.

anchor.surface_text: On December 13, 1951, the Conciliation Officer wrote to the appellant No. I and enclosed the demands of the Union which were dated August 9, 1951.

facts.text: On December 31, 1951, appellant No. 1 asked to appear before Conciliation Officer on January 9, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: On December 31, 1951, the appellant No. I was asked to appear before the Conciliation Officer on January 9, 1952, and after getting one adjournment the appellant No. I appeared before the Conciliation Officer on January 17, 1952, and filed its Written Statement and raised various objections.

facts.text: Appellant No. 1 appeared before Conciliation Officer on January 17, 1952 and filed Written Statement.

anchor.surface_text: and after getting one adjournment the appellant No. I appeared before the Conciliation Officer on January 17, 1952, and filed its Written Statement and raised various objections. The next date of hearing was January 31, 1952, and the proceedings went on till June 2, 1952

facts.text: Next hearing date was January 31, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The next date of hearing was January 31, 1952, and the proceedings went on till June 2, 1952, when the appellant No. 1 wrote to the Conciliation Officer saying that numberuseful purpose would be served by holding any further meetings.

facts.text: Conciliation proceedings continued till June 2, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: and the proceedings went on till June 2, 1952, when the appellant No. 1 wrote to the Conciliation Officer saying that numberuseful purpose would be served by holding any further meetings. On May 9, 1952, the Union had also indicated to the Conciliation Officer that the negotiations had failed.

facts.text: On May 9, 1952, Union indicated to Conciliation Officer that negotiations failed.

anchor.surface_text: On May 9, 1952, the Union had also indicated to the Conciliation Officer that the negotiations had failed. On March 18, 1952, the appellant dismissed Louis Pereira, a bus companyductor and proceedings were taken on a companyplaint by Assistant Commissioner of Labour under s. 33 read with s. 31 of the Act against 5 accused persons the two appellants and the partners of appellant No. 1.

facts.text: On June 2, 1952, appellant No. 1 wrote to Conciliation Officer that no useful purpose would be served by further meetings.

anchor.surface_text: when the appellant No. 1 wrote to the Conciliation Officer saying that numberuseful purpose would be served by holding any further meetings. On May 9, 1952, the Union had also indicated to the Conciliation Officer that the negotiations had failed.

facts.text: On March 18, 1952, appellant dismissed Louis Pereira, a bus conductor.

anchor.surface_text: On March 18, 1952, the appellant dismissed Louis Pereira, a bus companyductor and proceedings were taken on a companyplaint by Assistant Commissioner of Labour under s. 33 read with s. 31 of the Act against 5 accused persons the two appellants and the partners of appellant No. 1.

facts.text: Complaint filed by Assistant Commissioner of Labour under s. 33 read with s. 31 against 5 accused persons including the two appellants and partners of appellant No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: and proceedings were taken on a companyplaint by Assistant Commissioner of Labour under s. 33 read with s. 31 of the Act against 5 accused persons the two appellants and the partners of appellant No. 1. The Chief Presidency Magistrate acquitted all the accused including the appellants

facts.text: Chief Presidency Magistrate acquitted all accused on June 19, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Presidency Magistrate acquitted all the accused including the appellants and held that as the companyciliation proceedings had companytinued for a period of more than 14 days as from January 17, 1952, further proceedings for companyciliation were illegal and therefore the accused persons companyld number be companyvicted under s. 31 1 of the Act.

facts.text: Magistrate held conciliation proceedings continued more than 14 days from January 17, 1952, making further proceedings illegal.

anchor.surface_text: and held that as the companyciliation proceedings had companytinued for a period of more than 14 days as from January 17, 1952, further proceedings for companyciliation were illegal and therefore the accused persons companyld number be companyvicted under s. 31 1 of the Act. The State took an appeal to the High Court and the judgment of acquittal was reversed

facts.text: State appealed to Bombay High Court and judgment of acquittal reversed.

anchor.surface_text: The State took an appeal to the High Court and the judgment of acquittal was reversed and of the accused persons the two appellants were companyvicted and the others were acquitted. The two appellants have appealed by special leave.

facts.text: Bombay High Court convicted accused Nos. 1 and 5, sentenced No.1 to fine Rs. 250, No.5 to Rs. 50.

anchor.surface_text: thus companyvicting accused Nos. 1 5 under s. 31 1  read with s. 33 1  of the Industrial Disputes Act  XIV of 1947   hereinafter called the Act  and sentencing accused No. 1 to a fine of Rs. 250 and accused No. 5 to a fine of Rs. 50, The appellants are the Andheri Marol Kurla Bus Service who was accused No. 1

facts.text: High Court acquitted other accused persons.

anchor.surface_text: and of the accused persons the two appellants were companyvicted and the others were acquitted.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered by Kapur J. on April 21, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: 1959. April 21. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-This is an appeal by special leave against the judgment and order of the High Court of Bombay reversing the judgment of the Chief Presidency Magistrate, Bombay, and thus companyvicting accused Nos. 1 5 under s. 31 1  read with s. 33 1  of the Industrial Disputes Act

facts.text: Conciliation proceedings were pending when Louis Pereira was dismissed on March 18, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: As the companyciliation proceedings were pending at the time when Louis Pereira was dismissed the appellants were rightly companyvicted under s. 31 1  read with s. 33 of the Act.

facts.text: Appellants convicted under s.31(1) read with s.33(1) of Industrial Disputes Act 1947.

anchor.surface_text: reversing the judgment of the Chief Presidency Magistrate, Bombay, and thus companyvicting accused Nos. 1 5 under s. 31 1  read with s. 33 1  of the Industrial Disputes Act  XIV of 1947   hereinafter called the Act  and sentencing accused No. 1 to a fine of Rs. 250

facts.text: Supreme Court held conciliation proceedings conclude when report received by appropriate Government per s.20(2)(b).

anchor.surface_text: The companyciliation proceedings therefore do number end when the report under s. 12 -6  is made by the Conciliation Officer but when that report is received by the appropriate Government. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the February 4, 1955, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 1256 of 1954, arising out of the judgment and order dated June 19, 1954, of the Chief Presidency Magistrate, Bombay, in Case No. 176/S of 1953. Hardayal Hardy, for the appellants. J. Umrigar and B. H. Dhebar, for the respondent. 1959. April 21. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-This is an appeal by special leave against the judgment and order of the High Court of Bombay reversing the judgment of the Chief Presidency Magistrate, Bombay, and thus convicting accused Nos. 1 & 5 under s. 31(1) read with s. 33(1) of the Industrial Disputes Act, XIV of 1947 (hereinafter called the Act) and sentencing accused No. 1 to a fine of Rs. 250 and accused No. 5 to a fine of Rs. 50, The appellants are the Andheri Marol Kurla Bus Service who was accused No. 1 (appellant No. 1) and its Manager H. Khan who was accused No. 5 (appellant No. 2). Some disputes arose between the appellant No. 1 and its workmen.

thus convicting accused Nos. 1 & 5 under s. 31(1) read with s. 33(1) of the Industrial Disputes Act, XIV of 1947 (hereinafter called the Act) and sentencing accused No. 1 to a fine of Rs. 250 and accused No. 5 to a fine of Rs. 50, The appellants are the Andheri Marol Kurla Bus Service who was accused No. 1 (appellant No. 1) and its Manager H. Khan who was accused No. 5 (appellant No. 2). Some disputes arose between the appellant No. 1 and its workmen. On December 13, 1951, the Conciliation Officer wrote to the appellant No. 1 and enclosed the demands of the Union which were dated August 9, 1951. On December 31, 1951, the appellant No. 1 was asked to appear before the Conciliation Officer on January 9, 1952, and after getting one adjournment the appellant No. 1 appeared before the Conciliation Officer on January 17, 1952, and filed its Written Statement and raised various objections.

concepts.interpretation: Prohibits employer during pendency of conciliation proceedings from dismissing workmen concerned in the dispute without permission of the authority.

concepts.unlisted_description: Restrictions on alteration of conditions of service or dismissal during pendency of proceedings

anchor.surface_text: The Act provides for commencement and conclusion of conciliation proceedings under s. 20 but the first sub-section of s. 20 deals with what are called utility services and sub-s. (2) of that section provides as to when the conciliation proceedings conclude. That sub-section is as follows- S. 20(2) A conciliation proceeding shall be deemed to have concluded- (a) where a settlement is arrived at, when a memorandum of the settlement is signed by the parties to the dispute (b) where no settlement is arrived at, when the report of the conciliation officer is received by the appropriate Government or when the report of the Board is published under s.17, as the case may be or (c) when a reference is made to a Court, Labour Court, Tribunal or National Tribunal under section 10 during the pendency of conciliation proceedings. The provisions of sub-section (2) apply to all conciliation proceedings whether in regard to utility services or otherwise.

concepts.interpretation: Conciliation proceedings conclude when the report of the conciliation officer is received by the appropriate Government, not when made under s.12(6).

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: 0 during the pendency of companyciliation proceedings . The provisions of sub-section 2 apply to all companyciliation proceedings whether in regard to

anchor.surface_text: The conciliation proceedings therefore do not end when the report under s. 12(6) is made by the Conciliation Officer but when that report is received by the appropriate Government. It was contended that the conciliation proceedings should be held to terminate when the Conciliation Officer is required under s. 12(6) of the Act to submit his report but the provisions of the Act above quoted do not support this contention as the termination of the conciliation proceedings is deemed to take place when the report is received by the appropriate Government.

concepts.interpretation: Requires conciliation officer to submit report within 14 days of commencement but does not terminate pendency thereby; pendency ends per s.20(2)(b).

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: by the appropriate Government. The companyciliation proceedings therefore do number end when the report under s. 12 -6  is made by the Conciliation Of

when a reference is made to a Court, Labour Court, Tribunal or National Tribunal under section 10 during the pendency of conciliation proceedings.

issues.text: whether the companyciliation proceedings should be held to terminate when the Conciliation Officer is required under s. 12(6) of the Act to submit his report

anchor.surface_text: It was contended that the companyciliation proceedings should be held to terminate when the Conciliation Officer is required under s. 12(6) of the Act to submit his report but the provisions of the Act above quoted do number support this contention

arguments.claim: As the conciliation proceedings had continued for a period of more than 14 days as from January 17, 1952, further proceedings for conciliation were illegal and therefore the accused persons could not be convicted under s. 31(1) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Presidency Magistrate acquitted all the accused including the appellants and held that as the conciliation proceedings had continued for a period of more than 14 days as from January 17, 1952, further proceedings for conciliation were illegal and therefore the accused persons could not be convicted under s. 31(1) of the Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: s.20(2)(b) defines conclusion of proceedings as when report received by appropriate Government, not after 14 days under s.12(6)

arguments.claim: The object of conciliation is to get a settlement made with expedition and therefore under s. 12 the Conciliation Officer was bound to make his report within 14 days of the commencement of the conciliation proceedings; as 14 days had expired before March 18, 1952, the dismissal could not be said to be one within the words pendency of conciliation proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: The argument raised on behalf of the appellant is that the object of conciliation is to get a settlement made with expedition and therefore under s. 12 the Conciliation Officer was bound to make his report within 14 days of the commencement of the conciliation proceedings or within such shorter period fixed by the appropriate Government.

arguments.court_reasoning: s.12(6) time limit is directory; breach does not terminate pendency which is governed by s.20(2)(b)

arguments.claim: Conciliation proceedings conclude where no settlement is arrived at, when the report of the conciliation officer is received by the appropriate Government per s.20(2)(b).

anchor.surface_text: The Act provides for commencement and conclusion of conciliation proceedings under s. 20 but the first sub-section of s. 20 deals with what are called utility services and sub-s. (2) of that section provides as to when the conciliation proceedings conclude.

arguments.claim: The conciliation proceedings therefore do not end when the report under s. 12(6) is made by the Conciliation Officer but when that report is received by the appropriate Government.

anchor.surface_text: The conciliation proceedings therefore do not end when the report under s. 12(6) is made by the Conciliation Officer but when that report is received by the appropriate Government.

arguments.claim: s.12(6) contemplates submission within 14 days but does not affect pendency; proceedings do not automatically come to an end after 14 days but terminate as per s.20(2)(b).

anchor.surface_text: It is true that s. 12(6) of the Act contemplates the submission of the report by the Conciliation Officer within 14 days but that does not affect the pendency of the conciliation proceedings and if for some reason the Conciliation Officer delays the submission of his report his action may be reprehensible but that will not affect the interpretation to be put on s. 20(2)(b) of the Act.

arguments.claim: This is how s.20(2)(b) was interpreted in Workers of the Industry Colliery, Dhanbad v. Management of the Industry Colliery and Colliery Mazdoor Congress, Asansol v. New Beerbhoom Coal Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: This is how s. 20(2)(b) was interpreted in Workers of the Industry Colliery, Dhanbad v. Management of the Industry Colliery. It was next contended that on this interpretation the conciliation proceedings could be prolonged much beyond what was contemplated by the Act

holdings.text: The conciliation proceedings do not end when the report under s. 12(6) is made by the Conciliation Officer but when that report is received by the appropriate Government.

anchor.surface_text: The conciliation proceedings therefore do number end when the report under s. 12 -6  is made by the Conciliation Officer but when that report is received by the appropriate Government. It was companytended that the companyciliation proceedings should be held to terminate when the Conciliation Officer is required under s. 12 6  of the Act to submit his report but the provisions of the Act above quoted do number support this companytention as the termination of the companyciliation proceedings is deemed to take place when the report is received by the appropriate Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory language in s.20(2)(b) explicitly deems conclusion of proceedings when report received by appropriate Government, not upon making of report under s.12(6); supported by prior interpretation in precedents.

holdings.text: The provisions of sub-section (2) [of s.20] apply to all conciliation proceedings whether in regard to utility services or otherwise.

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of sub-section (2) apply to all companyciliation proceedings whether in regard to utility services or otherwise. All companyciliation proceedings under this sub- section shall be deemed to have companycluded in the case where numbersettlement is reached, when the report of the Conciliation Officer is received by the appropriate Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit statutory text in s.20(2) states applicability to all conciliation proceedings beyond just utility services mentioned in s.20(1).

holdings.text: s. 12(6) contemplates submission of report within 14 days but does not affect pendency of conciliation proceedings; delay in submission does not terminate proceedings which end per s.20(2)(b).

anchor.surface_text: It is true that s. 12 6  of the Act companytemplates the submission of the report by the Conciliation Officer within 14 days but that does number affect the pendency of the companyciliation proceedings and if for some reason the Conciliation Officer delays the submission of his report his action  1  1953 S.C.R. 428. may be reprehensible but that will number affect the interpretation to be put on s. 20 2  b  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.12(6) time limit is directory and breach (delay) reprehensible but does not override express definition of conclusion in s.20(2)(b); harmonious reading with duties under s.12.

holdings.text: The conciliation proceedings were pending at the time when Louis Pereira was dismissed; appellants rightly convicted under s.31(1) read with s.33 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: As the companyciliation proceedings were pending at the time when Louis Pereira was dismissed the appellants were rightly companyvicted under s. 31 1  read with s. 33 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dismissal on March 18, 1952 occurred before conciliation report received by government per s.20(2)(b), while proceedings ongoing beyond 14 days; applies prohibition in s.33(1)(b) making it offence under s.31(1).
